articles.headline: Fed Nominees Support Expanded Duties
articles.snippet: Three nominees to the central bank’s board told a Senate hearing that they supported ensuring financial stability and tightening oversight of the nation’s biggest financial institutions.
articles.abstract: Three nominees to the central bank’s board told a Senate hearing that they supported ensuring financial stability and tightening oversight of the nation’s biggest financial institutions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Hours before the Senate approved a far-reaching overhaul of Wall Street regulations on Thursday, President Obama’s three nominees to the board of the Federal Reserve said they were prepared to help the central bank handle its vastly expanded duties to ensure financial stability and oversee financial institutions.

articles.headline: Google Earnings Disappoint Investors
articles.snippet: The company’s revenue beat analysts’ expectations, but its profit missed expectations.
articles.abstract: The company’s revenue beat analysts’ expectations, but its profit missed expectations.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Like an impatient audience at intermission, Google’s investors are waiting for its second act.

articles.headline: From a Gulf Oyster, a Domino Effect
articles.snippet: The oil spill’s economic fallout has had a sneaky domino effect, touching the lives of everyone in the Gulf.
articles.abstract: The oil spill’s economic fallout has had a sneaky domino effect, touching the lives of everyone in the Gulf.

articles.headline: How to Tell a Nation Is at Risk
articles.snippet: Corporate strength , an economist argues, is a better gauge of debt problems than gross domestic product growth, or even government debt.
articles.abstract: Corporate strength , an economist argues, is a better gauge of debt problems than gross domestic product growth, or even government debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: Which governments will not be able to pay their bills?

articles.headline: Goldman Pays $550 Million to Settle Fraud Case
articles.snippet: The bank agreed to pay $550 million to settle claims that it misled investors with a subprime mortgage product.
articles.abstract: The bank agreed to pay $550 million to settle claims that it misled investors with a subprime mortgage product.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Goldman Sachs has agreed to pay $550 million to settle federal claims that it misled investors in a subprime mortgage product as the housing market began to collapse, officials said Thursday.
articles.byline: By Sewell Chan and Louise Story

articles.headline: F.D.A. Panel Votes Against Obesity Drug
articles.snippet: The advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration voted 10 to 6 that the safety concerns about Qnexa, from Vivus, overrode the potential benefits.
articles.abstract: The advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration voted 10 to 6 that the safety concerns about Qnexa, from Vivus, overrode the potential benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal advisory committee voted narrowly against endorsing a drug vying to become the first new prescription medicine for obesity in more than a decade, signaling heightened concerns for possible health risks associated with a new generation of diet pills.

articles.headline: Banks Seek to Keep Profits as New Oversight Rules Loom
articles.snippet: With the final approval of financial regulatory reform, banks have moved quickly to turn the rules to their advantage by adding new fees and revamping their derivatives operations.
articles.abstract: With the final approval of financial regulatory reform, banks have moved quickly to turn the rules to their advantage by adding new fees and revamping their derivatives operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: The ink is not even dry on the new rules for Wall Street, and already, the bankers are a step ahead of everyone else.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: With Settlement, Blankfein Keeps His Grip
articles.snippet: Goldman’s share price jumped on hopes that its chief and his bank had put one of the most embarrassing episodes in the bank’s recent history behind them.
articles.abstract: Goldman’s share price jumped on hopes that its chief and his bank had put one of the most embarrassing episodes in the bank’s recent history behind them.
articles.lead_paragraph: The word spread through Wall Street just before 3:30 Thursday afternoon: It looked as if Lloyd C. Blankfein had finally struck a deal.
